description.narrative: Providing fresh fruit, veal, sausage, and yogurt to refugees in targeted refugee center

• Since 2013 waves of refugees have crossed the Bulgarian border seeking support and assistance, reaching up to 12 000 people at a time. According to the State Agency for Refugees (SAR), only for the first months of 2014, more than 8000 people applied for asylum in Bulgaria (35% of them being children). By the end of 2014, beginning of 2015, the refugee flow has slowed down significantly as most refugees arriving from Syria, prefer alternative routes. • As of December, 2017, a total of 948 people live in 5 refugee camps – 3 in Sofia and 2 in Harmanli and Pastrogor. The situation is changing rapidly, as many of the asylum seekers plan to only stay for a short time in the country and others arrive. In this winter months many of the people that have searched for private accommodation in the summer return to the camps. • Food security is the major area of intervention in the project proposal. The state tender procedure for providing food items to the refugee camps is being delayed, which causes tension as feeding is at risk for about 948 people across the country, currently accommodated. There is need of meat, yogurt, and fruit for the month of January until the tender procedure is finalized. Until then, the Agency seeks alternative ways for providing for the needs of the refugees, such as the Bulgarian Red Cross, UNHCR, NGOs, private donors, businesses and CSOs working on the field.
